Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 10:43PM djd wrote: Kimmy called me once when I was in wound-care hell.  I remember feeling so grateful, as she was going through just as much, or more, than I was at the time.   We exchanged several cards over the last three years. I'll try to take comfort in knowing that Kimmy is pain-free, totally healthy, and in perfect peace now. Prayers and positive thoughts to her family, friends and all Kimmy's sisters who are grieving her loss. I just want to scream.  The emotion in my throat is choking me, and I can't write anything else without using swear words.  RIP, Kimmy.

Posts.Title: not good you guys Fitztwins Lindaip

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 08:56PM djd wrote: Deb, Your story about your dad on the plane reminds me of a story I heard several years ago - I think it was on 60 minutes or 48 hours or some show like that... Anyway, two people were sitting next to each other on a plane and started talking.  One was on her way to say goodbye to a young relative who was in a coma after a motorcycle accident before they pulled the plug on life support. The second person was on her way to visit a relative who was on his deathbed, in desperate need of some organ (I can't remember which one).  The reason they hadn't found a donor yet was because he had a rare blood type or something like that. They started making calls on the airplane phones and learned that the both of their relatives had the same blood type, etc.,  They frantically called family members and doctors several times during the flight.  By the time the plane landed, all the wheels were in motion to get the organ from the young man who was coming off life support to transplant in the other one who was running out of time. It was an amazing story and they had the transplant receipient on the show, along with both families.  Everyone involved remarked that it was clearly divine intervention from the heavens. Anyway, your story reminded me of that, and I have a sense of peace and hope for you.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 04:20AM djd wrote: Deb - You did NOT over-react.  To do anything less would have been under-reacting, like I did when I let a "rookie" poke around on me for over an hour to insert a central line.  I will NEVER make that mistake again.
Posts.Title: Did I over react? FIred a nurse yesterday.... AlaskaDeb snowyday

Posts.Content: djd wrote: No verdict yet, but the area of concern was originally one spot on 1 rib.  Now there are several spots on 3 different ribs. In explicably, my radiation oncologist (he just happened to be the one who ordered the tests) doesn't think it's anything but more broken ribs (wtf???) and wanted to "wait and see" for three more months.   I thought my mom was going to lose it and simply tackle him, she was so angry.   I said, okay whatever and went straight to my oncologist (in the same office) and he said no way, no how are we going to wait one more minute.  So, I had blood work today, a CT scan will be scheduled for next week, and an appointment next Wednesday with an orthopedic surgeon. This.sucks.a$$. Donna Dx 12/13/2004, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bone scan and xray results djd djd

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2008 04:18AM djd wrote: Celia and Mary- Thank you for the kind words and warm thoughts. Tender - thanks for the info regarding the pathology of bone mets.  I was wondering of ER/PR/HER2 status could vary from the original tumor. Luann - nothing on the sternum lit up.  I'm not sure what to make of that, as it is very tender to the touch. Ter - I'm not a confirmed metster yet, but I know I'll be in the right place if that's the diagnosis. Janis - I hear you.  The fact that my radiation onc was so dismissive does make me think that I'm okay - but the idea of not wanting to confirm what's going on is insane!!  MOTC - I lean more toward Absolute, but I like the way you think! Pam - Thanks for reassuring me that I am doing the right thing.  My mom has been through so much these last few years and there was no way she was going to tolerate any BS from an a-hole doctor! Thank you all for your concern.  I don't know how I would cope without you.

Posts.Title: Week of Shots Ends KariLynn cats_love_me

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 09:20PM djd wrote: Kari - You have earned the right to bitch!  Chemo sucks big time - no two ways about it. Ask them to give you a neulasta shot.  It works for the full 2 weeks instead of having to go back everyday for neupogen.  (Neulasta is more expensive, so I think the doctors try to please the insurance companies and go with the cheaper neupogen.) Also, I'm sure food tastes terrible right now -  I found salty foods were easier to eat and settled my stomach. Hang in there, girl - you can do this!
Posts.Title: Chemo is kicking my ass! KariLynn britbaby

Posts.Content: djd wrote: Hi all,  Kari's husband, Jon, just called to let me know that Kari passed away a short while ago.  I am too broken up to say more, but she instructed him to call me and that I would pass on the news.  Donna [Editing to add some details, now that I have regained my composure.] Kari was at home, surrounded by her loving family and she passed over peacefully.  She had been sleeping since Monday, which was the last time she was communicative, if I remember what Jon said correctly.  The kids had been staying at another family member's home for the last few days, so Jon took some time out to go see them this morning.  He received the call shortly after he arrived, and feels that Kari chose to wait until he and the kids were not in the house when she passed. Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 10:40PM djd wrote: Jule - The way that airmiles work is that there are so many seats available on any given flight that may be booked using FF miles.  With American, if you book a month in advance, you can usually get a round-trip tixket for 25K miles.  If you book it more short-term, it usually costs 40K miles, which is the most that any member can "gift" to another. The odds of getting the entire family on one plane are quite slim, especially given the  state of the economy and the effect that gas prices are having on the airlines. I would recommend taking the approach of getting all the family there, one way or the other, on the same day and leaving on the same day.  But don't count on getting everyone traveling on the same airline/flight, etc., I say we keep collecting the $$ and any miles, regardless of airline, and then see what there is to work with, and go from there. I feel really bad that LuAnn has so much on her plate already and is trying to manage this effort.  So, I will help however I can, if I can.
Posts.Title: helping a sister in need LuAnnH whoopsiedoodles

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 08:01PM djd wrote: Kari, I hate to hear this.  I just want to scream at the top of my lungs.  I don't know who I would scream at (God, Cancer Research Doctors, the World?)  but I am simply angry to the core to think that the disease is going to rob me of another dear friend.  Yes, that sounds selfish, but it is how I feel.  I can't imagine how your dear family can cope, but you have always been so strong, pragmatic, upbeat and able to find humor in this journey.   Crap, I am rambling... You have been such a great source of support to me and so many sisters over the last three years.  We are all with you in spirit, sending our prayers to you and your family.

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 09:28AM djd wrote: Kari, You have been such a dear friend to me.  I'll never forget when you called me after my brother was killed, just to see how I was doing.  It was the nicest thing anyone could have done and I was just amazed that you knew I needed someone besides my family to talk to. Like TheresaPW, Diane3Strikes, and way too many other sisters we have stood with as they began the next leg of this journey, you have been such a role model for being at peace with God and accepting God's will.  We will miss you, and we will pray for your family to find a way to cope at this awful time. I'm also praying that your journey to heaven will be glorious. Through tears, Donna
